channel.title: Steve Messer // Product manager
channel.description: Product person, GOV.UK, Government Digital Service. Web enthusiast, working in the open. Black Country boy living in London, UK.

item.title: This is how I work‚Ä¶give or take
item.description:
Dan wanted to see how I work, so here‚Äôs what I do, based on Jukesie‚Äôs rip-off of the Lifehacker ‚ÄòHow I Work‚Äô series. Other public service folk have written about how they work too.

Location: London, UK.

Current gig: Associate product manager, Government Digital Service.

Current mobile device: Samsung J5 for work, iPhone 8 for percy.

Current computer: MacBook Air 13‚Äù for work. Mac Mini at home. Some hobby Raspberry Pis and a PC too.

One word that best describes how you work: Metered.

First of all, tell us a little about your background and how you got to where you are today

Liked books and computers growing up. Spent a huge portion of my teenage years in my bedroom, tinkering on the Web or with computers. But I also enjoyed writing stories. Aged 16, I decided to focus on my Literature studies instead of Information Technology. It seemed to have‚Ä¶more prestige.

Did my A-levels, went to Bath Spa Uni to study Creative Writing. Bought a Mac to stop me playing video games. It worked, and I had a lot of fun. The course was excellent with great teachers ‚Äì check out some of the authors who‚Äôve also studied at Bath Spa ‚Äì and I had my sights set on a career in publishing.

Graduated. Spent the next year continuing cheffing, then quit to get some work experience and make the most of my degree. Spent two weeks as a managing editorial assistant at Vintage Publishing (part of Random House) and was asked back for another week. A few months later, there‚Äôs an open position as an editorial assistant and they ask me to apply. Incredibly, I get it and dive into the literary publishing world.

Do that for 9 months. Move on to Jonathan Cape, attend a Booker Prize ceremony in my first week. It‚Äôs quite glitzy, maybe too glitzy, especially for a working class boy from Wolverhampton. I get the chance to work with some of the most eminent, prolific literary authors in the world. They even let me commission a book of short stories. But I feel massively out of my depth and haven‚Äôt been to Oxbridge, like most others at my level. Self-doubt sets in. Work is naught but toil. I grow tired of the sausage factory. I quit.

And so I have a breakdown.

The clouds pass after 6 months and I get a job at NOW TV, which was just starting out. See Agile and software development in action. Turns out that‚Äôs quite glitzy too, except I didn‚Äôt know that at school. IT is kind of cool now. Hmm, maybe I could do tech after all. After some time in Operations, they initiate a TUPE process for an entire department and I need to find other work. Porism has an opening for someone.

First, I focus on increasing engagement and use of LG Inform Plus, then get the chance to redesign and launch a new version of eCasework. We spent a year on that before it went live. Take-up wasn‚Äôt good. I wrestled with marketing techniques, sales, developing some features and trying to talk to the few users we had. Wasn‚Äôt really sure what I was doing. It was‚Ä¶enjoyable, but also like banging my head against a brick wall. Repeatedly. Every day. Because I‚Äôm leading myself blind. (However, I also learn some cool stuff about open data, local government and generally learn tons from Mike.)

Explaining my anguish to a friend, he suggests that I‚Äôm kind of doing product management. I read a few blogs, try out the techniques, and they work. Hmm, maybe I could do tech after all. Attending the product management course at General Assembly gives me new skills. We start to grow eCasework and its user base. We develop features that people love. But I‚Äôm a bit hungry for more.

Apply for a job working on GOV.UK. They offer it to me. I‚Äôm overjoyed.

And now I‚Äôm just really, really happy. I‚Äôm at home. I‚Äôm back in my bedroom, tinkering on the Web and with computers, on a piece of the national infrastructure.

Take us through a recent workday

There‚Äôs a T-shaped structure to my week which I try to stick to. Mornings are for product thinking, writing cards or catching up on important emails, except on Wednesdays when I‚Äôll meet Alex for coffee. Then it‚Äôs a catch-up with Delivery Manager and Tech Lead, followed by stand-up with the team.

On Tuesdays and Wednesdays, the rest of the day is either meetings, team ceremonies or community meet-ups with other product managers.

Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays are a bit lighter: product thinking, analysing data and trends, and chats with other specialists, often dappled with the odd meeting here and there.

The details of what actually happens can be found in my weeknotes.

What apps, gadgets or tools can‚Äôt you live without?

Slack Reminders, my philosopher‚Äôs stone at work. With simple commands, I can remind myself or a colleague to do something. Need I say more? Since I have the app on my iPhone too, I can capture those work-related thoughts that spring up in the shower, at dinner or when I‚Äôm on holiday. It gets things out of my head, and only brings them back when needed.

Recently I‚Äôve been using Pocket a fair amount to save blogs to read. Medium‚Äôs Reading List also comes in handy, but I‚Äôm trying to move away from the platform.

But Twitter, too. It‚Äôs the app I use most. To both fill time productively and waste it.

I‚Äôve really taken to Post-it notes as a to-do list. I tried Trello but you‚Äôre not always able to add cards in meetings or ceremonies. Post-its are always at hand in GDS, so I can quickly capture sudden thoughts.

Here‚Äôs some stuff I‚Äôve used at work before.

What‚Äôs your best shortcut or life hack?

If you have to do something three times, automate it. If you can‚Äôt automate it, find a way to reduce the toil. You‚Äôll immediately create more time to spend on things that really need it.

Take us through an interesting, unusual, or finicky process you have in place at work

If you forget your work pass, you can‚Äôt get through many of the (mostly glass) doors. You end up staring forlornly at the people on the other side, who don‚Äôt know whether to let you in sans ID. Sometimes several people walk past before you‚Äôre permitted to exit your dimension of uselessness.

I haven‚Äôt worked out how to capitalise on this yet. It‚Äôs a bit like a cigarette break.

How do you keep track of what you have to do?

Like I said earlier, Slack Reminders and Post-it notes.

What‚Äôs your favourite side project?

I‚Äôm currently playing with Jekyll to refresh my website and move blog posts away from Medium. But I‚Äôm also running out of kimchi so will have to make some more of that soon.

What are you currently reading, or what do you recommend to read?

I‚Äôm reading Throwing Rocks at the Google Bus by Douglas Rushkoff for non-fiction, and Memoirs of Hadrian by Marguerite Yourcenar for fiction.

Who else would you like to see answer these questions?

Mike, Ellie, Alex, John, Emily and Femke.

What‚Äôs the best advice you‚Äôve ever received?

‚ÄòYou can do whatever you want in life, as long as you don‚Äôt hurt anyone.‚Äô Oh, and: ‚ÄòWork is just a way to pay the bills, but it helps if you enjoy it.‚Äô Both from my dad.

item.title: The Staying of the Course
item.description:
We‚Äôre reaching the mid-point of the quarter, so there‚Äôs a flurry of things going on. The team is chugging through work at a good pace, but there‚Äôs still so much to do if we‚Äôre to achieve the objective for our mission. Opening up conversation on how we‚Äôll meet those goals has been good, but we‚Äôre subject to so many external factors it can sometimes be tough to stay the course. (Sailing analogies are quite good for framing team-work and missions, I find.)

üñº ‚ÄòThe Storm‚Äô, Joseph Mallord William Turner, Amgueddfa Cymru (National Museum Wales)

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

Having migrated the first two applications over to a new hosting provider, we had a v-team retrospective with our friends in Reliability Engineering. It worked well, acting as a review of the steps we‚Äôd previously taken, giving us the chance to improve the run book for next time.

There was one gotcha to eliminate for next time: making sure that the release pipeline is clear and no one‚Äôs forgotten to release Puppet changes specifically. Our lead architect, Tim, reminded everyone that it was their responsibility to own a pull request (and associated changes) all the way through and to keep the deployment pipeline as clear as possible. Continuous delivery relies on principles rather than process.

Two

Had our first GOV.UK product manager fortnightly meet-up with the new Head of Product, Leanne. It was a bit full-on for her first session, but then again it was probably a perfect introduction for someone who‚Äôs going to own our high-level strategy for the forseeable future. We touched briefly on the product triage process ‚Äì which has dominated most fortnightly meetings in recent months ‚Äì and it was relatively trivial as opposed to the usual furore. That was good to see. Chatter about it had been dividing us as a community of late, but we were unified on it this week.

Rob used the Lean Coffee approach to decide what we‚Äôd talk about next. Everyone wanted to talk overwhelmingly about the roadmap and the next 12 months ‚Äì which, unfortunately, we‚Äôre not able to make public like in previous years. I‚Äôm not entirely certain on the reasons behind that but I don‚Äôt think it was an internal decision, because using roadmaps as an open communication tool is a principle we hold dear. I suspect it could be more to do with our roadmap being seen as a delivery plan rather than a strategy to achieving a multipart vision.

In my view, GOV.UK has pretty much (but not totally) achieved its product‚Äìmarket fit and should now be concerned with scaling. The issue we have is that new and existing departments on GOV.UK often bring solutionised features to us as problems, and many expect their requests to be built out. We have a good set of products and features to offer to government but I‚Äôm not sure where the sales process happens, and we need an amount of feedback from those interactions to influence our product iterations. In the meantime there‚Äôs plenty of work to be done on scaling the platform‚Äôs architecture and that‚Äôs something we can do with application- and machine-level data alone.

Three

Though it meant I missed a team lunch for a new starter on Platform Health, we took one and half hours out of a busy day to map the problem space of publishing, and it was really beneficial. Myself, Humin, Sam and Mark, all product managers on publishing aspects of the platform, wrote up the high level problems we see with scaling GOV.UK and grouped those by theme. It‚Äôs intended to form a strategy for solving those problems, but in a time when reliability is perhaps more important than efficiency, I‚Äôm not sure how much of it we‚Äôll be able to work on.

That aside, it was excellent to get together with PMs from across the programme and join up our thinking. I‚Äôve been meaning to do that ever since joining Platform Health, bringing other product teams and their goals into our team‚Äôs thinking. Because, arguably, I am currently a technical product manager whether I intended to become one or not. And technical product management has internal teams as its users.

I‚Äôve got a couple of product ideas bobbing around and have a hankering to scratch the ‚Äòbuild a thing‚Äô itch, so if you want to get involved in a side hustle, hit me up.

Four

Spent two hours coming up with options to upgrade and manage our Elasticsearch with Bevan. If I‚Äôm honest, I wasn‚Äôt really sure how to approach this, but I knew we needed a range of options plus their technical, financial and product-focussed impacts to present to the programme team for them to choose from. Sort of like a Choose Your Own Adventure business case.

A matrix of options plotted against risks, benefits, technical complexity, delivery time and financial costs

I freestyled a matrix of Post-it notes, detailing the different stages and options plotted against the risks, benefits, technical complexity, delivery time and financial costs of each. It actually worked quite well and we got all the brainstorming done inside of the meeting.

When a point was raised, there would usually be a counterpoint to consider for a different option, meaning we grew a body of thoughts quite quickly. Much better than scrolling up and down a document, scribbling in part-thoughts and half-formed sentences, which I‚Äôve done previously.

Five

Bevan covered how we code and quality assure products and features at GOV.UK. This was off the back of our retrospective, where Alan had asked to be introduced to our process and I was keen to hear about it too. We‚Äôd been told about it informally but found this proper session really useful. And it was good to understand the inner workings as compared to the development process at previous places I‚Äôve worked. It‚Äôs pretty fast at GOV.UK and everything‚Äôs to such a high quality, I was just really intrigued to know more.

It hangs off a set of principles rather than defined processes. I‚Äôm paraphrasing here, but essentially our developers

  • are responsible for their code and features throughout the development and release lifecycle,

  • should test their code and its dependencies,

  • have code peer-reviewed for quality,

  • should QA their code in integration, either individually or with product managers, and

  • use continuous delivery to release small, frequent changes.

There‚Äôs more in the GDS Way but bear in mind that this works for us and may not suit other teams.

Reflections

What I Learned

That all these facilitation techniques and Post-it noting practices are just methods for getting ideas out. Yes, I was skeptical at first and I know many people still are, but they work. If you‚Äôre struggling to have productive conversations at work and meetings go round in circles, try something different. There‚Äôs shitloads of blogs and other websites with loads of approaches you can try.

What I Could Do Better

Ask people to give feedback to my line manager. A colleague came over and praised me for some work, saying they‚Äôd pass it on, but I‚Äôve neglected to ask people to do that in the past. I‚Äôm going to make sure I know who line manages each person on our team, too, so I can furnish them with all the good work our people do.
